subject: Re: [junit] Re: Asserting Equality Of Collection Elements
msgSnippet: ... Sadly, you can only count them. ... It shouldn t. If it does, you re doing something else wrong. Post sample code if you re unsure. size() answers the
messageBody:
> I first check that the sizes are the same before doing a uni-
> directional "contains". That should take care of the situation where
> one collection is larger than the other. But, you bring up another
> point. How can I tell how many times an element appears in a
> collection, such as a map?

Sadly, you can only count them.

> If multiple elements hash to the same
> value is there a way to tell that their are multiple elements for
> that hashvalue? The size() method will only tell me how many hash
> values there are.

It shouldn't. If it does, you're doing something else wrong. Post sample code
if you're unsure. size() answers the number of distinct (according to equals
()) keys in the Map.

Remember, hashing is only used to get a "good first guess" of where an
element is located in a collection; other than that, hashing means nothing.
--
